column2: -My ideal little gentleman," sighed Aunt Petunia.

column1: te­nía unas gran­des ore­jas, pa­re­ci­das a las de un mur­ciéla­go
column2: had big ears, similar to those of a bat.

column1: y unos ojos ver­des y sal­to­nes del ta­ma­ño de pe­lo­tas de te­nis
column2: and bulging green eyes the size of tennis balls

column1: pero pen­só que so­na­ría de­ma­sia­do gro­se­ro
column2: but thought it would sound too rude

column1: —¿Quién es us­ted? —Do­bby, se­ñor. Do­bby a se­cas.
column2: -Who are you? Dobby, sir, just Dobby.

column6: can also be faltering/choked with emotion

column1: Ha­rry dio un bu­fi­do, se acer­có al elfo de un sal­to y tiró de él has­ta de­vol­ver­lo a la cama.
column2: Harry gave a snort/snarl, approached the elf and pulled him back onto the bed.

column1: Yo iré a la imprenta. Me pilla de camino a casa.
column2: I'll go to the printer's. It's on my way home.
-But won't they notice that you have slammed your ears in the oven door?

column1: Do­bby es­ta­ba al tan­to de su gran­de­za, se­ñor
column2: Dobby was aware of your greatness, sir.

column1: Le res­plan­de­cían los ojos gran­des y re­don­dos
column2: His big, round eyes were sparkling/gleaming
he said in a broken voice
